text: I have a feeling that they wouldn't since it is only at proposal stage. They would care more about results, figures, presentation, etc. than to coding practices, computational efficiency, etc. But this is just a hunch as I am not an evaluator, I just had some experiences from evaluators.

text: I think it is also part of the job in research with computational models. You would expect the same for an experimentalist but the examiner wouldn't be picky on the details of the procedures when these are well known (this is not the case if the experimenter is proposing a new technique or setup).

text: Personally I look at GitHub repositories when evaluating proposals and I've hammered a few proposals that have been poor in that regard - I look for a track record of contributions when I see generic statements like "we'll put all our code on GitHub". I don't set a very high bar (we all have lots of other things to be doing) but I get annoyed when people treat putting code online as a box ticking exercise - putting in a bit of postdoc time for packaging and documentation is only going to strengthen the proposal from my perspective.

text: I agree with you David regarding proper documentation and packaging. However, the record of contributions calls for another discussion: usually you wouldn't publicly post your code before you are certain of the publication; in this case you would have a private repo that then is changed to public or otherwise you could have a new repo for the public realm and the private that you use for the record of commits. We choose this option in our lab so it is common to find very few commits in a published paper's repo. What do you think?
